Graphical abstract Solid acid catalysts were successfully prepared using mesoporous silica (MESOSI) as support and tungstophosphoric acid (KTPA) as active phase, which was incorporated by impregnation (MESOSI#KTPA) and inclusion (MESOSI@KTPA). TEM (transmission electron microscopy) images of MESOSI samples revealed the presence of mesopores (worm-like structured) and well-defined pore channels. XRD patterns of MESOSI#KTPA samples showed small crystals of H3PW12O40·6H2O that were not present in the MESOSI@KTPA materials. The specific surface area of the MESOSI modified with KTPA decreases with the increment of the heteropolyacid content. 31P NMR and FT-IR characterizations confirmed the existence of undegraded [H3-XPW12O40]X− and [PW12O40]3− anions interacting with the SiOH2 + groups of MESOSI. Potentiometric titration results showed that both acid strength and number of acid sites increased with the KTPA loading in MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA samples. Moreover, the acidic properties of MESOSI#KTPA materials were remarkably higher than those of MESOSI@KTPA. The catalysts prepared were highly active, selective and reusable in the solvent-free synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine from 1,2-phenylenediamine and 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione. Keywords Mesoporous-microporous silica Tungstophosphoric acid 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine 1 Introduction Catalysis employing Keggin heteropolyacids (KHPAs) is a field of great interest and ongoing growth [1]. In the last decades, KHPAs have been applied in numerous laboratory and industrial scale processes due to their redox and photochemical properties, high Brønsted acidity, thermal stability, variety of structure and size. Medicine [2–4], environment [5–7], biomass [8–10], surfaces [11] and sensors [12] are some of the areas where the heteropolyacids have had the greatest impact. Regarding their structure, KHPAs are protonic acids that incorporate complex anions called polyoxometalates. The Keggin structure consists of [XM12O40]n− anions where X is the heteroatom (P, Si) and M is the transition metal (Mo, W). The primary structure of heteropolyanions consists of an XO4 tetrahedron surrounded by a compact network of twelve octahedral MO6. These octahedra are organized into four M3O13 groups called triads [13]. The oxygen atoms that form the primary structure have equivalent symmetry and can be classified into four classes: internal oxygens, oxygens that connect the M3O13 groups through the vertices, oxygens that connect the octahedra through the edges to form the triads, and terminal oxygens. KHPAs can be used in their bulk form in heterogeneous catalysis, though it is advisable to support them because the bulk compounds present a very low specific surface area (∼ 1−5 m2/g), which limits their use in this manner. To overcome this disadvantage, the KHPAs are dispersed on a proper solid support, where the Keggin structure remains intact and immobilized. Titania, carbon, alumina, zeolites and zirconia have shown good results as KHPA supports due to their high specific surface area (SSA) and adequate pore size [14,15]. Silica has frequently been used for this purpose due to its neutral or slightly acidic properties, high SSA values and easy synthesis by sol-gel chemistry method [16,17]. MCM-41 (Mobil Crystalline Materials No. 41) [18,19] and SBA-15 (Santa Barbara Amorphous No. 15) [20] are two of the best-known ordered mesoporous silicas. Han et al. [21] presented the preparation of a silica that exhibits an increment in the micropore area with respect to SBA-15. Bimodal structures with meso and micropores improve the diffusion of reactants and therefore, the catalytic activity of mesoporous materials. On the other hand, KHPAs can be immobilized through electrostatic interaction using functionalized Merrifield resins (originally developed for the solid-state synthesis of peptides) [22] and functionalized silica spheres [23]. Indeed, several measurements exhibited in the present paper are similar to those displayed in the article where KHPAs were grafted on silica microspheres [24]. Nowadays we are studying the use of different mesoporous siliceous materials such as core-shell polystyrene-silica and hollow silica microspheres, with the aim of immobilizing KHPAs and thus obtain heterogeneous acid catalysts [25]. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one report in which the mesoporous silica materials, synthesized according to the procedure described by Han et al., are used as KHPA support [26]. One possible route for incorporating KHPAs into the support is its direct impregnation. For this, the support is put in contact with a solution of the active phase and then the solvent is eliminated by thermal treatment [27]. Besides, another method called “inclusion” consists of embedding KHPA into the support network during its synthesis [28]. Depending on the synthesis method and experimental conditions used (such as solvent, temperature, reagent ratio, ageing and calcination temperature) the KHPAs will interact differently with the support [29]. In this sense, a suitable support preparation method and KHPA incorporation will allow an increase of the reactant accessibility to the acidic protons of the heteropolyacid, due to their dispersion on the material with high SSA. Benzodiazepines and derivatives form a family of nitrogenous heterocyclic compounds important from the point of view of their pharmaceutical and agrochemical applications. These compounds display properties such as antidepressant, antiallergenic, anticonvulsant, analgesic, anti-inflammatory, antiviral, anticancer, antifungal, antibacterial and herbicide activity [30–35]. The most conventional strategies for the synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepines involve a condensation reaction in presence of an acid catalyst, between 1,2-phenylenediamine with 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds or β-haloketones. Catalysts used can include ionic liquid [36], MgBr2 [37], Yb(OTf)3, AgNO3 [38], MgO-POCl3 [39], molecular iodine [40]. The development of Green Chemistry has suggested the use of catalysis as a fundamental tool with the aim of reducing the energy needed to carry out the process, increasing conversions and selectivity. Additionally, it can minimize the formation of toxic wastes [41]. In particular, the replacement of traditional liquid catalysts by solid supported KHPAs presents advantages such as their easy recovery from the reaction medium, reusability and the possibility of avoiding corrosion problems. Moreover, solvent-free protocols are becoming more popular with the purpose of modernizing classical ones that employ organic solvents that can produce harmful effects on the environment and human life [42]. Thus we would be dealing with a simple and eco-friendly experimental procedure. In this context, this paper details the synthesis and characterization of MESOSI@KTPA catalysts (tungstophosphoric acid included in mesoporous silica) prepared for the first time by modifying the synthesis of Han et. al.: different loadings of KTPA were incorporated during the support synthesis. Catalysts with the same KTPA content prepared by the impregnation of MESOSI (MESOSI#KTPA) were also synthesized and characterized for comparative purposes. The catalytic activity of the obtained catalysts was evaluated in the one-pot solvent-free reaction between 1,2-phenylenediamine and 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione to obtain the corresponding 1,5-benzodiazepine. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pluronic P123 (Poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol), PEO20PPO70PEO20), Aldrich; HCl 36 % v/v, Anal Quim; distilled water; TEOS (tetraethyl orthosilicate), Sigma-Aldrich; H3PW12O40 (tungstophosphoric acid, TPA) 99 %, Fluka, were used for the synthesis of supports and catalysts. For the catalytic tests, 1,2-phenylenediamine 99 %, Sigma-Aldrich; 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione 98 %, Sigma-Aldrich, were employed. 2.2 Synthesis of MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI#KTPA samples MESOSI was synthesized using the method based on sol-gel chemistry, reported by Han et al. [21]. This technique consists of the acid hydrolysis of TEOS and the use of P123 as mesoporous template (see supplementary material), which is eliminated by calcination at 500 °C for 2 h. The technique described by Han et al. was modified to obtain MESOSI@KTPA catalysts with 30 % and 40 % of heteropolyacid in the final material. The inclusion of HPA in the support was done by adding tungstophosphoric acid together with TEOS. The required mass of KTPA was previously dissolved in water-ethanol 50 % (v/v) solution. The solids obtained were calcined at 500 °C for 2 h. The obtained catalysts were called MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA40 with 30 % and 40 % TPA loading, respectively. This synthesis is detailed in supplementary material. For comparative purposes, the support MESOSI was impregnated with tungstophosphoric acid to obtain catalysts with TPA loading of 30 % and 40 % w/w that were called MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40, respectively. This procedure is also described in supplementary material. 2.3 Materials characterization N2 adsorption/desorption measurements were carried out at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C) using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 equipment. From the obtained data, the specific surface area (SBET) was determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller model [43], the micropore area (SMIC) by the t-plot method, and the mean pore diameter (Dp) by the BJH method [44]. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy analysis (FT-IR) was carried out with Bruker IFS 66 equipment, in the 400–4000 cm−1 range at room temperature. Raman spectroscopy was performed with Bruker FT Raman model Ram II, in a spectral range 2000−43 cm−1, excitation line at 1064 nm, 300−700 mW of power, 2000–4000 scans of accumulations. X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were obtained employing PANalytical X´Pert PRO 3373/00 equipment, using Cu Kα radiation, 40 mA and 40 kV in the high voltage source. Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ss-NMR) experimental data were acquired with a Bruker Avance-III HD spectrometer equipped with a 14.1 T narrow bore magnet operating at Larmor frequencies of 600.09, 242.92 and 119.21 MHz for 1H, 31P and 29Si, respectively. Powdered samples were packed into ZrO2 rotors and rotated at room temperature at different magic angle spinning (MAS) rates. 31P and 29Si ss-NMR spectra were recorded using high powered decoupling (hpdec) experiments at a MAS rate of 15 kHz in 3.2- and 2.5-mm MAS probes, respectively. 1H-MAS ss-NMR spectra were recorded in a 2.5 mm MAS probe using single pulse excitation experiments at a MAS of 30 kHz. Two-dimensional 1H-31P heteronuclear correlation (HETCOR) experiments were done in pure TPA and SA30 samples using 1H→31P cross-polarization for magnetization transfer (contact time 1.5 ms) at a MAS rate of 15 kHz. Chemical shifts for 1H and 29Si (in ppm) are relative to (CH3)4Si. For 31P, a phosphoric acid solution (H3PO4, 85 %) was used as standard (0 ppm). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained with a Physical Electronics PHI 5700 spectrometer with non-monochromatic Mg Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, and 1486.6 eV) and a multichannel detector. Spectra were recorded in the constant pass energy mode at 29.35 eV, using a 720 μm diameter analysis area. Charge referencing was measured against adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.8 eV). A PHI ACCESS ESCA-V6.0 F software package was used for data acquisition and analysis. A Shirley-type background was subtracted from the signals. Recorded spectra were always fitted using Gaussian–Lorentzian curves in order to determine the binding energies of the different element core levels more accurately. The morphology of the catalysts was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), using FEI Talos F200X equipment (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) that combined outstanding high-resolution TEM and STEM with a HAADF imaging with industry-leading energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) signal detection, and chemical characterization with compositional mapping. The samples were suspended in isopropyl alcohol and dropped onto a perforated copper film grid. The acidic properties of the solids were estimated by potentiometric titration, suspending the solid in acetonitrile and titrating with an n-butylamine solution in acetonitrile. The potential variation was measured in a Metrohm 794 Basic Titrino, with a double junction electrode. 2.4 Catalytic test Catalysts were tested in the solvent-free synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine from 1,2-phenylenediamine and 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione. In a representative experiment, 0.25 mmol of 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanodione, 0.5 mmol of 1,2-phenylenediamine and the catalysts (1% mmol of KTPA relative to dione) were added in a tube test with magnetic stirring, equipped with a reflux condenser. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at 90 °C. The reaction progress was checked by thin-layer chromatography (TLC). Then, the reaction mixture was extracted with hot toluene (3 × 2 mL). The fractions collected were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and the solvent was evaporated. The solid was purified by silica gel column chromatography using a mixture of solvents hexane-ethyl acetate in proportion. This solvent ratio was varied to (7:3), (6:4) and (5:5), with the objective of increasing the polarity of the eluent mixture, to give the pure benzodiazepine. 2.5 Catalyst reuse The catalysts MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA30 were recovered from the reaction medium by filtration, washed with toluene (4 mL), and dried in an oven at 90 °C, until constant weight. Both catalysts were reutilized in four successive reaction cycles. 2.6 Product identification Pure benzodiazepine was characterized by comparison of retention time in TLC, melting point using a standard sample prepared by conventional methods, and 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra. They were recorded on a Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer in DMSO-d 6 using tetramethylsilane as internal standard. The signals obtained from 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6) were δ 3.72 (br s, 2 H); 7.38 (dd, 2H, J =3 Hz, 6 Hz); 7.40–7.47 (6H, m); 7.62 (dd, 2H, J =3 Hz, 6 Hz); 7.99–8.01 (4H, m), and from 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d 6) were δ 35.3, 125.6, 128.4, 128.6, 128.7, 130.9, 137.6, 140.7, 154.2. Finally, the pure product exhibited a melting point in the range 137−138 °C [45]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties The synthesized catalysts were subjected to N2 adsorption/desorption measurements with the aim of assessing their main textural properties. The obtained results are summarized in Table 1 . The MESOSI nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms (Figure S1) are of type IV according to IUPAC classification with H2 hysteresis loops, typical of mesoporous materials [46]. The main features of the MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI#KTPA isotherms (Figure S2) are quite similar to those of MESOSI, which remain unchanged after the incorporation of KTPA. On the other hand, it can be observed that MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA40 SBET values (454 and 314 m2/g, respectively) are significantly lower than that of MESOSI (834 m2/g) certainly due to the incorporation of 30 % and 40 % w/w of KTPA into the silica matrix. Additionally, the SMIC ratio decreases slightly, which may be due to a decrease in the cross-linking level when the acid concentration increases. This is in agreement with reports in the literature that indicate a similar behavior for the specific surface of mesoporous titania obtained via sol-gel process [47,48]. The specific surface area of the KTPA impregnated MESOSIs (MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40) decrease (404 and 285 m2/g, respectively) with the increment of the heteropolyacid content. The reduction of the specific surface area values can be mainly explained considering that the SBET of bulk KTPA is very low (3−5 m2/g), and its proportion in MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 materials is 30 % and 40 % respectively. In addition, it could also be attributed to the partial blocking of the MESOSI micropores by the KTPA anion (main diameter 1.2 nm). This assumption is in agreement with the lower proportion of micropore area (SMIC) in the impregnated MESOSI samples and with the VMIC decrement. 3.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The X-ray diffraction pattern of KTPA (Fig. 1 ) displays a series of intense diffraction peaks at 2θ (hkl) = 10.2 (011), 14.5 (002), 17.8 (112), 20.6 (022), 23.1 (013), 25.3 (222), 29.3 (004), 31.1 (114), 32.9 (024), 34.5 (233), 37.7 (015), 40.6 (125), 42.0 (044), 44.7 (244), 45.9 (235), 48.4 (145), 53.2 (055), 59.8 (237), 61.9 (455), 65.0 (288), and 70.0° (338), characteristic of the H3PW12O40·6H2O (JCPDS N° 98-009-2218). MESOSI XRD pattern shows a broad signal between 15 and 30°, typical of amorphous silica. The supports impregnated with 30 % and 40 % of heteropolyacid exhibit very low intensity peaks (marked with * in Fig. 1) corresponding to H3PW12O40·6H2O as described above. Taking into account the cross-sectional area of the KTPA anion is equal to 1.13 nm2, the percentage of total surface area of MESOSI “cover” by KTPA ranged from 12.0%–18.8% for MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40, respectively. However, the presence of small crystals of H3PW12O40·6H2O suggests that a low amount of KTPA is not well dispersed on the silica surface. Taking into account that in the XRD patterns of MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 after being washed with water for 8 h, the weak reflection lines assigned to H3PW12O40·6H2O crystals are still present, this can suggest that the largest proportion of these small crystals seems to be strongly attached to the silica surface. In the case of silica-included KTPA catalysts (data not shown), diffraction patterns do not show any of the characteristic H3PW12O40·6H2O reflection lines or for other hydrates [25]. This fact suggests that the heteropolyacid is well dispersed within the silica matrix as a noncrystalline phase, unlike what happened for the samples obtained by impregnation of MESOSI. 3.3 Infrared and Raman spectroscopy Raman and infrared spectroscopies are complementary techniques for the study of molecular vibrations. Where, ionic bonds tend to give strong IR signals and covalent bonds strong Raman signals. The FT-IR spectra of the MESOSI, KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA samples are shown in Fig. 2 . The FT-IR spectrum of MESOSI sample shows the typical bands of SiO2 (Table 2 ) and do not show any of the template P123. For the MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA40 samples, FT-IR spectra reveal the presence of the P-Oa, W-Od, and W-Ob-W KTPA bands (Table 2) overlapping those of the support [25]. This effect becomes more clear when a higher content of TPA is incorporated into the support [49] and it confirms the presence of the [PW12O40]3− anion. Moreover, we can see that MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 samples (data not shown) exhibit the same main features. Signals corresponding to lacunar [PW11O39]7− and dimeric [P2W21O71]6− anions are not observed [50]. The Raman spectra of MESOSI, bulk H3PW12O40 and KTPA supported and included in silica are shown in Fig. 3 . Tungstophosphoric acid exhibits two strong signals at 1006, 990 cm−1 and a weak one at 900 cm−1, which correspond to the stretching vibrations of PO, WO and W-Oc-O bonds of the Keggin unit, respectively [51]. For MESOSI sample, due to the low polarizability and the ionic character of the Si-O bonds we do not observe any band in the Raman spectrum. The Raman spectra of MESOSI#KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA materials present the characteristic peaks of KTPA but broadened and shifted. This shifting can be attributed to the interaction among the Keggin anion and the Si−OH2 + species (due to the transfer of protons to silanol groups) present in MESOSI samples, in a similar way to what has been proposed for KTPA-TiO2 and KTPA-ZrO2 materials [52,53]. Furthermore, as a result of the KTPA content increment in the samples, the intensity of signals increases. In addition, no signals corresponding to decomposition of [PW12O40]3− into WOx species (generally placed at 714 and 803 cm-1) are observed. FT-IR and Raman spectroscopy results suggest that KTPA heterogenization by either incorporation during the MESOSI synthesis or its impregnation (followed by its thermal treatment) is a suitable method to obtain a heteropolyacid-silica composite keeping the [PW12O40]3− Keggin structure intact. 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy The morphological features of the catalysts were studied by transmission electron microscopy. Worm-like mesostructured, well-defined pore channels and their short-range arrangement can be observed in Fig. 4 . Besides, studies performed by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) show a homogeneous distribution of W and P elements in the MESOSI#KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA samples (Fig. 5 ) [54]. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) Surface composition, oxidation states of tungsten on the surface and possible interactions between the heteropolyacid and the support were studied by XPS analysis. In Fig. 6 A, the O 1s spectra for the MESOSI, MESOSI@KTPA, MESOSI#KTPA and KTPA materials are represented. MESOSI material exhibits a peak at 532.9 eV, which is associated with Si–O silica bonds [55]. KTPA shows two distinct contributions (Fig. 6 B), the first one at 531.2 eV (78 %) and the second at 532.55 eV (22 %). These signals could be associated with the presence of WOW and WOP bonds, respectively [56]. The incorporation of heteropolyacid in MESOSI matrix generates a slight shift in the O 1s signal to lower binding energy (BE) due to the interaction of KTPA with the support. Moreover, a much weaker signal (<5%) appears in the range 530.9–531.2 eV (Fig. 6 B). This latter component has a binding energy similar to that described for pure tungstophosphoric acid. The W 4f core level spectrum for pure H3PW12O40 shows a well-resolved doublet with binding energy values at 36.1 eV and 38.2 eV corresponding to the W 4f 7/2 and W 4f 5/2, respectively (Fig. 7 A). In the case of MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA30 samples, the characteristic W 4f broad and poorly resolved doublet is present. The doublet intensity and resolution increase in the case of MESOSI@KTPA40 and MESOSI#KTPA40 samples, being more similar to that of the bulk heteropolyacid. The deconvoluted of W 4f core level spectra for bulk heteropolyacid and MESOSI#KTPA40 sample are shown in Fig. 7 B. These results suggest that W species exist in two different states in all cases. The major contribution has a BE that corresponds directly to that observed in bulk KTPA and is associated with the existence of Keggin units on the silica surface that are typical of W(VI) species. The minor component appears at lower BE and could be associated with the formation of WOx-type oxides in which W is present with an oxidation state lower than VI as a consequence of the partial decomposition of tungstophosphoric acid on the support surface or a perturbed tungstate environment. However, the idea of the existence of perturbed tungstate environments, similar to that reported by Newman et al. [57], turns out to be the most appropriate. According to the model proposed by Newman, each Keggin anion interacts with the silica surface through three terminal WO bonds. The results of the deconvolution are included in Table 3 . The intensity ratio of the two contributions, W6+/ W6+pa, shows a constant factor of 3:1 no matter the KTPA content, in accordance with the proposed model. The relative contributions from these states only deviate once multilayer/crystallite growth commences. It is seen that this ratio increases for the included catalysts and therefore included samples show a greater proportion of perturbed W6+ species. The atomic surface composition of both families of samples is listed in Table 4 . The W and P surface exposure increased for the samples with higher KTPA loadings regardless of the synthesis procedure employed. Comparing both methods, W/P ratio was close to that presented by the bulk KTPA, meanwhile included samples evidenced a much higher surface enrichment of tungsten species. 3.6 Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ss-NMR) studies In order to obtain information regarding the nature of the KTPA species present in the MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI#KTPA materials, 1H, 31P and 29Si ss-NMR experiments were done. The results are shown in Fig. 8 . The 29Si ss-NMR spectra (Fig. 8 A) for the different materials show similar profiles of the Qn resonance signals corresponding to the inherent chemical structure of these silicon materials. Thus, Q4, Q3 and Q2 peaks (assigned to Si (OSi)4, Si (OSi)3OH and Si (OSi)2(OH)2 silicon sites) resonate at a 29Si chemical shift (δ 29Si) of -110.7, -101.4 and -91.6 ppm, respectively. According to the population of each Qn peak in the MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA30 samples (obtained from the quantitative ss-NMR experiments, Table 5 ), it is possible to infer that the incorporation of KTPA increases the Q3/Q4 and Q2/Q4 intensity ratios in comparison with the MESOSI material. The 31P ss-NMR spectrum (Fig. 8, B) of bulk KTPA (H3PW12O40.6H2O) shows one peak at -15.5 ppm with a shoulder (-15.3 ppm) that are assigned to the [PW12O40]3− (which interacts with H+(H2O)2 species) and [H3-XPW12O40] X− Keggin anions, respectively [52,58,59]. The incorporation and the interaction of KTPA molecules with the silica framework produce the downfield shift of the 31P signals. The downfield shift observed (-15.2 ppm), compared to that of the KTPA, is due to the electrostatic interaction among the [H3-XPW12O40]X− anions and the Si−OH2 + groups present in MESOSI@KTPA (MESOSI#KTPA) samples. Neither the KTPA content nor the way in which the sample was synthesized seems to influence the position and the line width. The 31P signals are quite similar in terms of FWHM and 31P chemical shift values. Additionally, the signal tail can be attributed to the presence of KTPA hydrates such as H3PW12O40.6H2O. The tail is more intense in the case of MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 samples. The thermal treatment of H3PW12O40.6H2O at temperatures higher than 160 °C removes water molecules from H+(H2O)2 species and leads to the formation of [H3PW12O40] [60]. As a result of the thermal treatment, the amount of [H3-XPW12O40]X− anions interacting with SiOH2 + groups increases according to: [PW12O40]3− + 3H+(H2O)2 + X (SiOH) → X(SiOH2)+[H3-XPW12O40]X−+ 6H2O On the other hand, samples prepared by inclusion of KTPA during the MESOSI synthesis (MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA40 samples) and calcined at 500 °C show a new resonance signal at -14.3 ppm, not present in samples prepared by impregnation (MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 samples). This new signal is assigned to the formation of KTPA-SiO2 complex via the formation of SiOW bonds. According to Legagneux et al. [61], SiOW bonds between KTPA and SiO2 can be formed by thermal treatment at temperatures higher than 300 °C through: (SiOH2)+[PW12O40]3− →( SiOWPW11O39)2− + H2O The 1H ss-NMR spectrum (Fig. 8 C) of bulk KTPA (which has not been previously dehydrated) sample shows signals at around 6.0, 7.1 and 8.9 ppm that can be attributed to interstitial water molecule clusters (H2O) n , water clusters such as H+(H2O)n, and highly acidic protons associated with H3O+ species, respectively [62]. Also, protons in isolated (nonhydrogen-bonded) water molecules are very weak, and narrow signals at 1.0 and 3.5 ppm are present in bulk KTPA. In the case of MESOSI sample, the main 1H NMR signal (placed at 3.9 ppm) is assigned to physisorbed water molecules that involve weakly hydrogen-bonded hydroxyls. Additionally, broad 1H resonance signals at 6–7 and 1.8 ppm can be associated with water molecules that are strongly hydrogen-bonded to the SiOH protons of the MESOSI framework and isolated silanol groups, respectively [63,64]. The very weak signals at 3.5 and 1.0 ppm are ascribed to protons in isolated (nonhydrogen-bonded) water molecules. The proton values for water molecules are commonly found in crystalline or semicrystalline organic compounds [65] as well as in metal-organic framework composites [66]. The presence of KTPA molecules in the MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA30 materials produces the shift of the main silica 1H NMR signal to higher frequency values (4.7 and 4.9 ppm, respectively), which may indicate an increasing hydrogen bond strength in the samples. Additionally, it is important to mention that none of the three main 1H NMR signals characteristic of the KTPA is present in the KTPA-silica samples. The changes in the NMR spectra indicate a fast exchange between all silanol groups and water molecules ascribed to the good dispersion of the heteropolyacid within the silica framework, being independent of the synthetic method used to incorporate the heteropolyacid. Remarkably, the 2D 1H-31P HETCOR experiments (Fig. 8 D) confirmed the incorporation of the KTPA molecules into the silicon framework due to the 2D NMR changes observed from its pure state in MESOSI#KTPA30 (Fig. 10). The incorporation of the heteropolyacid shows a new interaction between the phosphorus of KTPA molecules (δ 31P: -15.4 ppm) and the proton of the silicon core at 4.7 ppm, verifying the inclusion and the interaction with the Q3 and Q2 sites. 3.7 Acidity measurements The acidity properties of the synthetized materials were estimated from the potentiometric titration with n-butylamine curves (Fig. 9 ). According to the potentiometric results (Table 6 ) all the materials exhibit Ei values higher than 100 mV [67] assigned to the presence of very strong acid sites (see the classification scale in supplementary material). However, the materials prepared by impregnation of the support (MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 samples) presented higher acid strength than in the case of silica-included KTPA catalysts (MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA40). The area under the curve allows estimating the number of acid sites (NAS). For example, the titration curves of the MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40 samples reveal the presence of a higher number of acid sites (90 and 169 meq n-butylamine/g, respectively) than those of the MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA40 materials (68 and 81 meq n-butylamine/g, respectively). For the MESOSI@KTPA catalysts, the lower NAS values obtained by this technique compared to the materials obtained by impregnation of MESOSI with KTPA solutions (MESOSI#KTPA samples) are assigned to the fact that part of tungstophosphoric acid is present inside the silica matrix, and it is not accessible to the n-butylamine molecules. However, both groups of catalysts show that the acid strength and the number of sites increase with the increment of the amount KTPA incorporated into the support. 3.8 Catalytic test The catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts was studied in the solvent-free synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine as is represented in Fig. 10. The best temperature, substrate molar ratio, amount of catalyst and reaction time were determined in the reaction using bulk tungstophosphoric acid as catalyst. To evaluate the influence of temperature, blank experiments were carried out at 25, 40, 80 and 90 °C (see supplementary material). In all cases 0.25 mmol of dione and 0.5 mmol of diamine were stirred for 1 h in the absence of a catalyst and solvent-free conditions. According to these results, the following catalytic tests were carried out at 90 °C for being the best experimental conditions that allow us to evaluate the catalytic performance of the materials. In this case, the reaction yield was less than 5%. Then the catalytic activity of the MESOSI sample was evaluated under the same reaction conditions. The MESOSI material showed a low activity for the formation of the corresponding 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine (yield 18 %). The optimum molar ratio of substrates was studied using bulk KTPA as catalyst. Three tests were carried out using different 1,2-phenylenediamine/1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione (A/D) molar ratios (1/1, 2/1 and 3/1) and 1 mmol % of KTPA with respect to dione, agitation without solvent, at 90 °C for 1 h. The results obtained are shown in Table 7 , entries 1–3. In all cases good reaction yields were obtained. However, employing molar ratios higher than 1/1 (entries 2 and 3) a slight increment in the reaction yield was observed (60 % and 63 %, respectively). In the same way, the optimum catalyst amount was evaluated using 0.5, 1 and 2 mmol % KTPA with respect to dione, A/D molar ratio equal to 2/1, under the experimental conditions previously mentioned (Table 7, entries 2, 4 and 5). The yield decreases or remains unchanged when 0.5 and 2.0 KTPA mmol % are used. In order to evaluate and select the best reaction time for comparing the catalytic performance of the prepared materials, a series of tests (Table 8 ) at 90 °C (for 15, 30, 60 and 120 min) and others at lower temperatures (25 and 50 °C) with longer reaction time (until 3 h) were performed. In all cases, a molar diamine:dione ratio of 2:1, 1 mmol % of KTPA with respect to dione was used. A poor yield was obtained (only 25 %) after 15 min at 90 °C (Table 8, entry 1). The yield increases when the reaction is followed for 30 and 60 min (Table 8, entry 2 and 3, respectively) but it remains practically unchanged after 120 min (Table 8, entry 4). Moreover, at lower temperatures (25 and 50 °C) no detectable reaction between 2-phenylenediamine and 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione takes place after 120 min. Only at 50 °C and after 360 min a 30 % of conversion was achieved (Table 8, entries 5 and 6). The MESOSI#KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA materials were evaluated in the selected reaction under the following conditions: A/D molar ratio 2/1, with stirring at 90 °C for 1 h in solvent-free conditions. The catalyst amount of MESOSI#KTPA30/MESOSI@KTPA30 and MESOSI#KTPA40/MESOSI@KTPA40 was selected in order to maintain the KTPA content equal to 0.01 mmol with respect to dione (24 and 18 mg, respectively). The results obtained are listed in Table 9 . The catalysts prepared by impregnation of MESOSI with KTPA (Table 9, entries 2 and 3) show a slightly better catalytic performance than those prepared by KTPA inclusion (Table 9, entries 4 and 5). This behavior is in agreement with the higher acid strength and number of acid sites present in MESOSI#KTPA catalysts revealed by potentiometric titration. For the MESOSI#KTPA as well as for MESOSI@KTPA catalysts, the yield increases with the increment of the KTPA content in the material, which is due to the increment of the number of acid sites present in the resulting material. Employing supported KTPA allowed us to isolate and reuse the catalyst from the reaction medium by an easy and eco-friendly process. Finally, MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA30 were reused in four consecutive reaction cycles, showing excellent results towards the formation of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine. The reaction yield only decreased by 1% with respect to the first use. After each test, more than the 90 % of the catalyst was revovered (less than 2 mg of MESOSI#KTPA30 and MESOSI@KTPA30 were retained in the filter used for the separation) 4 Conclusions In this paper, acid solid catalysts were prepared by impregnation (MESOSI#KTPA) and inclusion (MESOSI@KTPA) of tungstophosphoric acid in mesoporous silica (MESOSI). Their textural, structural and acidity properties were evaluated and they were applied in the synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine from 1,2-phenylenediamine and 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione. MESOSI#KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA materials showed specific surface area (SBET) in the range 545−285 m2/g, mainly assigned to the presence of mesopores. FT-IR and Raman characterizations confirmed that the Keggin structure of KTPA remained intact after the impregnation/inclusion and calcination processes. EDX studies confirmed a homogeneous distribution of heteropolyacid on the MESOSI matrix. 31P MAS NMR characterizations showed the presence of the undegraded [PW12O40]3− and [HXPW12O40](3−X)− species interacting electrostatically with the SiOH2 + groups present in the MESOSI material. The thermal treatment at temperature higher than 300 °C led to the formation of SiOW bonds. Furthermore, potentiometric titration studies revealed that MESOSI#KTPA materials exhibited greater acid strength than MESOSI@KTPA. The total acidity is strongly dependent on the method used to incorporate the heteropolyacid but almost independent of the KTPA content. Although both series of catalysts (MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI#KTPA) are very active and highly selective in the synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepines, the better catalytic performance of the latter is due to its higher acidic properties. Due to our interest in eco-friendly protocols, 3H-1,5-benzodiazepines can be synthesized in solvent-free conditions using MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI#KTPA with very good reaction yields. coredata.dc:description: Solid acid catalysts were successfully prepared using mesoporous silica (MESOSI) as support and tungstophosphoric acid (KTPA) as active phase, which was incorporated by impregnation (MESOSI#KTPA) and inclusion (MESOSI@KTPA). TEM (transmission electron microscopy) images of MESOSI samples revealed the presence of mesopores (worm-like structured) and well-defined pore channels. XRD patterns of MESOSI#KTPA samples showed small crystals of H3PW12O40·6H2O that were not present in the MESOSI@KTPA materials. The specific surface area of the MESOSI modified with KTPA decreases with the increment of the heteropolyacid content. 31P NMR and FT-IR characterizations confirmed the existence of undegraded [H3-XPW12O40]X− and [PW12O40]3− anions interacting with the SiOH2 + groups of MESOSI. Potentiometric titration results showed that both acid strength and number of acid sites increased with the KTPA loading in MESOSI@KTPA and MESOSI@KTPA samples. Moreover, the acidic properties of MESOSI#KTPA materials were remarkably higher than those of MESOSI@KTPA. The catalysts prepared were highly active, selective and reusable in the solvent-free synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepine from 1,2-phenylenediamine and 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedione.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous acid catalysts prepared by immobilization of H3PW12O40 on silica through impregnation and inclusion, applied to the synthesis of 3H-1,5-benzodiazepines
